text:
Hudson Ave., north from Fulton Street, showing the B.M.T. Elevated lines. This is the Fifth Ave., Bay Ridge Elevated Fulton Street Station.

1900.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Nevins Street, south from Flatbush Ave. Also Flatbush Ave., west side, east from Nevins Street. This view is no longer existent. The buildings were razed, to make way for the new Fox Theatre, a motion picture house.

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.

IDENTIFICATION: Aerial view of Brooklyn, showing Flatbush and Fulton St.
DATE: 1 May 1928
PHOTOGRAPHER: Fairchild Aerial Surveys, Inc.
270 W. 38, NYC
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS: Held by Photographer
title: General view - [Brooklyn - Flatbush Avenue and Fulton Street.]

text:
Flatbush Ave. (foreground), east side, south from the intersection of Fulton Street and Flatbush Ave. The Fulton Street Elevated line of the B.M.T. is shown winding its way eastward on Fulton Street. In the background colonnaded is the Masonic Temple located at Lafayette and Clermont Aves. The Myrtle Ave. Line is on Flatbush Ave. (foreground). This view also shows a general view eastward.

August 12, 1929.

A general view northwestward from No. 1 Hanson Place, the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building, showing the business center of Brooklyn. Running across the face of the view from the lower left-hand corner is Flatbush Avenue, with the B. M. T. "El" on it, and its Fulton Street station. The bare-faced building forming a triangle in the center is the Fox Theatre Building, at Livingston Street. The auto-parking space is at Third Avenue (trolley tracks) and Schermerhorn Street, this area being known as Temple Square. In the distance is the Lower Manhattan skyline.

In the lower right-hand corner of view 2 is the Hotel Granada, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place. The thoroughfares seen in view 3 running from the fore- to the background (left to right) are: State Street, Schermerhorn Street, and Livingston Street.

May 12, 1939
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

title: General view - Brooklyn.

text:
Fulton Street, east from and across Flatbush Avenue Extension, underneath the B. M. T. elevated. The four-story building (center) is the Witteman Building and is on the east side of Flatbush Avenue Extension.

View 1: April 27, 1940
P. L. Sperr
View 2: June 21, 1941
View 3: July 14, 1941

View 2 shows the "El" being dismantled.
View 3: The "El" is gone.

view 2: Neg. No. A-1048

Flatbush Avenue, at Fulton Street, looking south, showing the old Fox Theatre Building being razed. The new Fox is on the left.

P. L. Sperr
